repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Second Rural and Main Roads
            Project : redacted report

abstracts.cdata!:
This report on the Second Rural and Main
            Roads Project of Guatemala provides the findings of an INT
            administrative inquiry (the Investigation) into allegations
            of corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, and/or coercive
            practices, as defined by the WBG for purposes of its own
            policies, rules and procedures (the WBG's Framework
            regarding Anti-corruption), in relation to the WBG-supported
            activities. The purpose of the Investigation was to allow
            the WBG to determine if the WBG's Framework regarding
            Anti-corruption has been violated. This Report is being
            shared to ensure that its recipients are aware of the
            results of the INT Investigation.

repnme.cdata!: Guatemala - Rural and Main Roads Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural and Main Roads
            Project for Guatemala were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory; the risk to development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was satisfactory; and the Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            The financing of maintenance activities is the single
            largest challenge in the rural roads sector, particularly in
            highly centralized countries. Central to success is working
            out the mechanisms to ensure that the adequate resources
            will be made available on a sustainable basis. Whereas
            central government transfers may remain an important
            contributory factor, it will be prudent for specific funding
            mechanisms to be designed for rural road maintenance,
            including local level resource mobilization from road users.
            Maintenance arrangements which rely on community based
            organizations are a valid approach but present certain
            limitations, particularly when there are no contractual
            arrangements linked to payments for services. Addressing the
            maintenance issues not only implies designing cost effective
            mechanisms but also delivery methods (micro-enterprises for
            example) that can be consistently applied in the local
            context. There is a need to balance expectations between
            local employment generations arising from rural roads works
            and efficient execution. The usually small scale of rural
            road works, coupled with the reasonable objective of most
            rural roads programs of generating local employment, often
            result in small local companies being awarded rehabilitation
            works contracts. This can result in execution delays as
            small contractors often lack the financial strength and
            equipment required to undertake multiple works
            simultaneously in an expeditions and efficient manner. A
            careful analysis of the bidding eligibility criteria and the
            possible inclusion of success fees for timely completion of
            works can constitute efficient instruments to partially
            solve this situation.

repnme.cdata!: Guatemala - Rural and Main Roads Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Rural and Main
            Roads Project in Guatemala are to 1) support building up of
            the country's institutional capacity to administer and
            maintain rural roads; 2) improve the rural road system in
            the ZONAPAZ region, specifically the Department of San
            Marcos (part of the geographic area most affected by
            internal conflict before the December 1996 Peace Accords,
            where the government is focusing a major post-conflict
            development effort), critical to providing access to social
            and other public services and fostering economic development
            through integration to markets; and 3) continue to improve
            the efficiency of the main and secondary road networks. The
            components are three: 1) to develop and implement a national
            rural roads and transport strategy; 2) to implement a pilot
            rural roads component using innovative institutional
            arrangements for maintenance and rehabilitation including
            the testing of new technologies for cost-effective
            strengthening of rural road surfaces, and pilot a new
            institutional framework for road management and financing;
            and 3) to continue support, through consultant services and
            providing equipment, for rehabilitating the main and
            secondary road network.
